snippet: Prosecutors oppose the New York State legislation, first introduced in 1999, but backers say it is gaining support.
abstract: New York State legislators will consider a bill that would keep the possession of condoms from being used in criminal court as evidence of prostitution; bill was first introduced in 1999, and has been re-introduced every year since, but has never passed; backers express optimism for passage this year; legislation is meant to protect the health of prostitutes who, fearing arrest if they are carrying condoms, have unprotected sex.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors oppose the New York State legislation, first introduced in 1999, but backers say it is gaining support.

headline.seo: Albany Bill Would Bar Condoms as Evidence of Prostitution
headline.main: State Bill Would Bar Condoms as Prostitution Evidence
headline.print_headline: State Bill Would Bar Condoms as Prostitution Evidence
